docs.title: Chem224: Symmetry-based Approaches to Electronic Structure and Spectroscopy
docs.text: Instructor: Jeffrey Rinehart

docs.title: Course Description
docs.text:
A symmetry-based approach to the electronic structure of molecular and extended solid structures with a focus on building chemical intuition for experimentalists. The course material will cover:

  • Fundamentals of point and space group symmetry
  • Group theory as an organizing principle for electronic structure
  • Applications of discrete and continuous symmetry for describing molecules, metals, and semiconductors
  • Understanding the underlying principles of spectroscopic techniques for research applications

docs.title: Basics of Hilbert Spaces and Quantum Mechanics
docs.text:
Chem224 - Jeffrey Rinehart - Fall 2023

Week 0-1: Applied Spectral Theory in Hilbert Space: A Quantum Chemistry Primer & Motivation for Symmetry and Group Theory in Spectroscopy

Objectives

  1. Understand course objectives
  2. Get to know each other and the interests of the class
  3. Hilbert Spaces and Quantum Mechanics
  4. Understand Dirac notation and its application in describing atomic orbitals
  5. Understand the role of symmetry in quantum mechanics and spectroscopy

docs.title: Basics of Hilbert Spaces and Quantum Mechanics¶
Hilbert Spaces¶
docs.text:
Definition: A Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ is a complete inner product space. That means it's a vector space equipped with an inner product $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ that is complete in the sense that every Cauchy sequence in $\mathcal{H}$ converges to an element in $\mathcal{H}$.

  • Inner Product: A function $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle: \mathcal{H} \times \mathcal{H} \to \mathbb{C}$ that satisfies certain properties like linearity, conjugate symmetry, and positive-definiteness.

  • complete: A space is complete if every Cauchy sequence in the space has a limit that also resides within the space.

This means that a Hilbert space is one that defines distances between vectors using the projection of one vector onto another. For Example: the wavefunction of a molecule projected onto a basis vector composed of atomic orbitals is an inner product that would give the "distance" along each basis vector

docs.title: A Familiar Hilbert Space: The Atomic Orbitals and Dirac Notation¶
Dirac Notation: The Basics¶
docs.text:
• Ket: A ket $| \psi \rangle$ represents a column vector (state vector) in a Hilbert space. It describes the state of a quantum system.

    $$ | \psi \rangle = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ a_2 \\ \vdots \\ a_n \end{pmatrix} $$

  • Bra: A bra $\langle \phi |$ represents the conjugate transpose (Hermitian conjugate) of the corresponding ket. It's essentially a row vector.

    $$ \langle \phi | = ( | \phi \rangle )^\dagger = \begin{pmatrix} a_1^* & a_2^* & \cdots & a_n^* \end{pmatrix} $$

  • Inner Product: $\langle \phi | \psi \rangle$ gives a complex number. It's akin to the dot product in classical vector spaces but is way more general and powerful. Because it can essentially take the very complicated spaces of wavefunctions and linearize them - making any solution to the Schrödinger equation a vector in the Hilbert space (i.e a linear combination of some orthonormalized basis vectors)

    • Matrix Form:

      $$\langle \phi | \psi \rangle = \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i^* b_i$$

    • Integral form:

      $$\langle \phi | \psi \rangle = \int \phi^*(\mathbf{r}) \psi(\mathbf{r}) d\mathbf{r}$$

    Here, $\phi^*(\mathbf{r})$ is the complex conjugate of the wave function $\phi(\mathbf{r})$, and $d\mathbf{r}$ is the volume element.

  • Outer Product: $| \psi \rangle \langle \phi |$ is a generalization of the cross product to any dimensionality. It expands the number of dimensions to define the total space of two or more vectors and creates a new Hilbert space.

    • translates operator language into matrix language (i.e. an abstract transformation into a representation of that transformation in a basis).

    $$ | \psi \rangle \langle \phi | = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 b_1^* & a_1 b_2^* & \cdots \\ a_2 b_1^* & a_2 b_2^* & \cdots \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots \end{pmatrix} $$

docs.title: Dirac Notation and Atomic Orbitals¶
docs.text:
• Atomic orbitals are solutions to the Schrödinger equation for electrons in atoms.
  • Let's take the hydrogen atom as an example. The wavefunction $\psi_{n, l, m}(r, \theta, \phi)$ can be described as a ket $| n, l, m \rangle$.

docs.title: Example: 1s Orbital¶
docs.text:
• 1s orbital corresponds to $n=1, l=0, m=0$.
  • In Dirac notation: $| 1, 0, 0 \rangle$.

docs.title: Example: Overlap Integral¶
docs.text:
• The overlap integral between two orbitals $\phi_a $ and $ \phi_b$ is:

    $$ \langle \phi_a | \phi_b \rangle = \int \phi_a^*(r, \theta, \phi) \phi_b(r, \theta, \phi) d\tau $$

  • In Dirac notation, this is simply:

    $$ \langle a | b \rangle $$

    Don't worry - we never have to use the integral form of the inner product in practice! The matrix form allows us to transform and simplify $\langle a | b \rangle$ without ever having to calculate the integral itself!

docs.title: Summary¶
docs.text: Dirac notation provides a clean, mathematical framework for using quantum mechanical principles on complex systems. This will be very important to spectroscopy and with a general understanding of the rules you can easily figure out the rules of any measurement or even make up new ones!

docs.title: Operators in Dirac Notation¶
docs.text:
• Adjoint Property and Self-Adjoint Operators The adjoint of an operator $\hat{A}$ is another operator $\hat{A}^\dagger$ defined in such a way that for every pair of vectors $|u\rangle$ and $|v\rangle$ in the Hilbert space, the following relation holds:

$$ \langle u | \hat{A} | v \rangle = \langle v | \hat{A}^\dagger | u \rangle^* $$

Here, the $^*$ denotes complex conjugation.

  • conjugate transpose of an operator
  • In Dirac notation, $\hat{A}^\dagger$ acts on bras just like $\hat{A}$ acts on kets.

Hermitian Operators

If an operator is Hermitian it means that $\hat{A} = \hat{A}^\dagger$. This is common for operators that correspond to observable quantities.

$$ A = A^\dagger \quad \text{and} \quad \langle \psi | A | \phi \rangle = \langle \phi | A | \psi \rangle^* $$

  • Symbols:

    • $A$: An operator acting on states in Hilbert space
    • $A^\dagger$: The adjoint (Hermitian conjugate) of $A$
    • $\langle \psi | A | \phi \rangle$ and $\langle \phi | A | \psi \rangle^*$: Inner products involving $A$

  • Why is it important? Self-adjoint operators are crucial because they correspond to physical observables. Their eigenvalues are always real.

docs.title: 3. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors¶
docs.text:
• Mathematical formulation: $$ A | \psi \rangle = \lambda | \psi \rangle $$ $$ A | \psi \rangle = \lambda | \psi \rangle $$

  • Symbols:

    • $A$: The operator
    • $|\psi\rangle$: Eigenvector corresponding to eigenvalue $\lambda$
    • $\lambda$: Eigenvalue

  • Why are they important? Eigenvalues and eigenvectors give us the possible outcomes and states, respectively, for measurements of the associated observable.

docs.title: Hilbert Space and Atomic Orbitals¶
docs.text:
In quantum mechanics, the state of a system is described by a vector in a Hilbert space. For atomic orbitals, the relevant Hilbert space is the space of square-integrable functions. We can define a square integrable function as one that satisfies the equation $$ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |\psi(\mathbf{r})|^2 d\mathbf{r} < \infty $$ for all $\psi(\mathbf{r})$ in the Hilbert space. In Dirac notation, we can write this as $$ \langle \psi | \psi \rangle < \infty $$ for all $| \psi \rangle$ in the Hilbert space. The condition that the wavefunction is square integrable is necessary for the inner product to be well-defined, but it need not include the entire Hilbert space. For instance, the space of spherical harmonics is a subspace of the space of square-integrable functions that is a useful basis for describing atomic orbitals.

Let's look at a common example of a basis chosen from the subspace of spherical harmonics. The spherical harmonics are a complete orthonormal basis for the Hilbert space of square-integrable functions. Thus, according to the spectral theorem for Hilbert spaces, the spherical harmonics form a complete set of eigenfunctions for the Hamiltonian operator. Many families of functions can be used as a basis for the Hilbert space of square-integrable functions, but the spherical harmonics are particularly useful because they are eigenfunctions of the angular momentum operator so we can use them to describe atomic orbitals. Ideally we always want to use a basis that looks as close as possible to the answer we expect so that the basis we put in looks a lot like the basis we get out. We get much more intuitive results this way.

Let's say we wanted to describe a particular molecular interaction involving a $-CH_2$ fragment and focus on the carbon orbitals in particular. Let's skip the actual functions for now and just assume we have orthonormal basis vectors described by the hydrogenic atomic orbitals. We can write these as e.g. $|1s\rangle$, $|2s\rangle$, $|2p_x\rangle$, $|2p_y\rangle$, and $|2p_z\rangle$, $|3s\rangle$, etc. We know that chemically, the most important orbitals are the $2s$ and $2p$ orbitals, so if we want to simplify our basis, we can limit it to

$$ \text{Basis} = \{ |2s\rangle, |2p_x\rangle, |2p_y\rangle, |2p_z\rangle \} $$

docs.title: 2. Spectral Decomposition¶
docs.text:
A useful property of Hilbert spaces that we can use is the spectral decomposition.

The spectral decomposition of an operator $\hat{A}$ is given by:

$$ \hat{A} = \sum_i \lambda_i | u_i \rangle \langle u_i | $$

Where $\lambda_i$ are the eigenvalues and $|u_i\rangle$ are the corresponding eigenvectors.

For example, if we're considering the Hamiltonian operator $\hat{H}$, the eigenvalues $\lambda_i$ would be the energies $E_i$, and each element $| u_i \rangle \langle u_i |$ forms a projection operator that projects onto the eigenspace corresponding to the eigenvalue $E_i$ to form a complete set of basis vectors for the Hilbert space.

In our example, the Hamiltonian operator would be:

$$ \hat{H} = E_{2s} |2s\rangle \langle 2s| + E_{2p_x} |2p_x\rangle \langle 2p_x| + E_{2p_y} |2p_y\rangle \langle 2p_y| + E_{2p_z} |2p_z\rangle \langle 2p_z| $$

and the matrix representation of this operator in the given basis would be:

$$ \begin{pmatrix} E_{2s} & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & E_{2p_x} & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & E_{2p_y} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & E_{2p_z} \end{pmatrix} $$

docs.title: 3. Outer Products and Operators¶
docs.text:
The power of forming a basis is that we can use it to describe any vector in the Hilbert space and any operator that acts on the vectors in the Hilbert space. This means we can form operators to describe interactions between any two vectors in the Hilbert space. In our example, let's say we know that the carbon will form an $sp$ hybrid orbital. This means that we can form an operator that describes the interaction between the $2s$ and $2p_x$ orbitals. In the operator formalism of quantum mechanics, this Outer Poduct, $|a\rangle \langle b|$, is

$$ \hat{J}_{s-px} = |2s\rangle \langle 2p_x| + |2p_x\rangle \langle 2s| $$

and the total Hamiltonian operator would be:

$$ \hat{H} = E_{2s} |2s\rangle \langle 2s| + E_{2p_x} |2p_x\rangle \langle 2p_x| + E_{2p_y} |2p_y\rangle \langle 2p_y| + E_{2p_z} |2p_z\rangle \langle 2p_z| + J (|2s\rangle \langle 2p_x| + |2p_x\rangle \langle 2s|) $$

or if we call the uncoupled Hamiltonian $\hat{H}_0$:

$$ \hat{H} = \hat{H}_0 + J_{s-p_x} (|2s\rangle \langle 2p_x| + |2p_x\rangle \langle 2s|) $$

Its matrix form in the given basis would be:

$$ \begin{pmatrix} E_{2s} & J & 0 & 0 \\ J & E_{2p_x} & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & E_{2p_y} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & E_{2p_z} \end{pmatrix} $$

docs.title: 4. Symmetry and Operators¶
docs.text:
An operator commutes with a symmetry operation if the system is invariant under that symmetry. For inversion symmetry:

$$ [\hat{I}, \hat{J}_{s-px}] = 0 $$

where $\hat{I}$ is the inversion operator. $\hat{J}_{s-px}$ is the operator describing the interaction between $2s$ and $2p_x$ $[A,B]$ is a commutator which is defined as: $$ [A, B] = AB - BA $$

In our example, inversion symmetry restricts $J$ to be zero, as $2s$ is gerade and $2p_x$ is ungerade:

$$ \quad \hat{i} |2s\rangle = |2s\rangle \\ \quad \hat{i} |2p_x\rangle = -|2p_x\rangle $$

This means that the terms $|2s\rangle \langle 2p_x|$ and $|2p_x\rangle \langle 2s|$ will cancel each other out to retain the symmetry of the system. This makes intuitive sense since inversion symmetry generates equal and opposite positive and negative wavefunction overlap between $2s$ and $2p_x$.

docs.title: 5. Symmetry and Eigenvalues¶
docs.text:
Symmetry operations can also be used to determine the degeneracy of eigenvalues. For example, if we consider the $2p_x$ and $2p_y$ orbitals, we can see that they are degenerate because they are related by a symmetry operation:

$$ \hat{C}_{2z} |2p_x\rangle = |2p_y\rangle $$

where $\hat{C}_{2z}$ is the $C_{2z}$ rotation operator. This means that the $2p_x$ and $2p_y$ orbitals retain their degeneracy under $C_{2z}$ rotation.

docs.title: Week 1-1: Symmetry and Point Group Review
Week 1-1: Symmetry and Point Group Review¶
Objectives¶
docs.text:
1. Understand basic symmetry elements
  2. Review point group notation

docs.title: Terminology¶
docs.text:
• Point group - A set of symmetry operations that can be performed on a molecule that leave the molecule in an indistinguishable state.
  • Symmetry operation - A movement of a molecule that leaves the molecule in an indistinguishable state.
  • Symmetry element - A geometric object (line, plane, or point) about which a symmetry operation is performed.
  • Symmetry representation - Any mathematical formalism that describes the transformation of an object under a symmetry operation. We will generally use matrices to represent symmetry operations.
  • Matrix Representation A mathematical formalism allowing us to algorithmically apply symmetry to a basis set of coordinates.
  • Basis set - An inner product space (usually of vectors) that has properties suitable for representing wave functions. e.g. a set of atomic orbitals.
  • Spectral theory - general set of theorems that allow us to decompose a matrix into a set of eigenvectors and eigenvalues based on the symmetry of the matrix.
  • Eigenvector - A vector that is not changed by a transformation. The transformation only scales the vector by a constant.
  • Eigenvalue - The constant by which an eigenvector is scaled by a transformation. In the context of quantum mechanics, a key eigenvalue is the energy of a system determined by the Hamiltonian operator, $\hat{H}$.
  • Metric - A function that defines the distance between two points in a space. In the context of quantum mechanics, $d(\psi, \phi) = \sqrt{\langle \psi - \phi | \psi - \phi \rangle}$, defines the metric on an inner product space describing the distance beween two wavefunctions. In Cartesian space, the metric is the distance between two points, $|\vec{r}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}$.
  • Inner product - A function that takes two vectors and returns a scalar. In the context of quantum mechanics, $\langle \psi | \phi \rangle$ is the inner product of two wavefunctions. In Cartesian space, $\vec{r} \cdot \vec{r'} = x x' + y y' + z z'$ is the inner product of two vectors. Represents a projection of one vector onto another.
  • Outer product - The outer product of two vectors $|a\rangle$ and $|b\rangle$ in a Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ is an operator $|a\rangle\langle b|$ that acts on the vectors in $\mathcal{H}$. Mathematically, it's defined as:

$$ |a\rangle\langle b| : \mathcal{H} \rightarrow \mathcal{H}, \quad |c\rangle \mapsto |a\rangle\langle b|c\rangle $$

A symmetrized outer product can be used as an "exchange" operator, e.g. $$\hat{J}_{ex} = \frac{J}{\sqrt{2}}(|1s_A\rangle\langle 1s_B| + |1s_B\rangle\langle 1s_A|)$$ where $J$ is a scaling constant for the magnitude of the interaction for symmetric contribution from exchanging $|1s_A\rangle$ and $|1s_B\rangle$.

docs.title: General Symmetry Transformation¶
docs.text:
In general, a symmetry operation is a transformation that can be described by a matrix. Here, and in many of the simple examples we will look at early on, we define our transformation using the Cartesian coordinate system. In this system, a point in space can be described by a set of three coordinates, $x,y,z$ where each coordinate is a real number, mathspeak: $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$. Another way to describe this is to use a vector, $\vec{r}$, where $\vec{r} = (x,y,z)$ and $\vec{r} \in \mathbb{R}^3$. This description is very useful for looking at the mathematical formalism of symmetry operations. For instance, we can describe the Cartesian space using the unit vectors, $\hat{x}, \hat{y}, \hat{z}$, where $\hat{x} = (1,0,0)$, $\hat{y} = (0,1,0)$, and $\hat{z} = (0,0,1)$ which is a basis set for the Cartesian space because any point in the Cartesian space can be described as a linear combination of these unit vectors. For instance, $\vec{r} = x\hat{x} + y\hat{y} + z\hat{z}$. We can also describe the vector $\vec{r}$ as a magnitude, $|\vec{r}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}$ which defines the metric of the space meaning that there is a well defined meaning to the idea of distance in the space. We can also define a unit vector, $\hat{r}$, that points in the direction of $\vec{r}$, where $\hat{r} = \frac{\vec{r}}{|\vec{r}|}$. This means that any vector has a direction independent of its magnitude meaning it can be normalized and scaled independently (two vital properties of a basis set and an eigenspace).

A symmetry operation is a transformation that takes a point in space and transforms it to a new point in space. The transformation is described by a matrix, $T$, that takes the coordinates of the original point and transforms them to the coordinates of the new point. The matrix is applied to the coordinates of the original point as follows:

$$ T:(x,y,z) \rightarrow (x',y',z') $$

where $x',y',z'$ are the coordinates of the transformed point. In matrix form,

$$ \begin{bmatrix} x' \\ y' \\ z' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} $$

docs.title: Mirror Plane Transformation:¶
docs.text:
Position Example Transformation Transformation Matrix General $\sigma_{h}$ $\sigma_{h}:(x,y,z) \rightarrow (x,y,-z)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$ on $\sigma$ $\sigma_{h}$ $\sigma_{h}:(x,y,0) \rightarrow (x,y,0)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \mathbb{I}_2$$

Note that when we apply the transformation to a point on the mirror plane, the point is unchanged. This is a general property of symmetry operations. A point on a symmetry element is unchanged by the symmetry operation.

docs.title: Mirror Examples:¶
docs.text: Name Description $\sigma_{h}$ 'Horizontal' mirror plane: Perpendicular to $C_n$ axis $\sigma_{v}$ 'Vertical' mirror plane: Parallel to $nC_2$ axes $\sigma_{d}$ 'Diagonal' mirror plane: Split the angle between the $nC_2$ axes $\sigma'(xy)$ specific coordinate mirror plane: when required, coordinates are used to remove ambiguity

docs.title: Rotational Transformations¶
docs.text:
Unlike mirror symmetry, rotational transformations retain the "sense" of the object in the space. This means that they can be either clockwise (-) or counterclockwise (+). The rotation axis is a unit vector, $\hat{n} = (n_x, n_y, n_z)$, where $n_x^2 + n_y^2 + n_z^2 = 1$. Point Group symmetry uses rotation axes as the primary means to classify groups meaning the highest n rotation axis is the primary axis of symmetry whereby other symmetry elements are defined. Sometimes this axis will be $C_1$.

In the most general case for 3D cartesian coordinates, a rotation about an axis, $\hat{n}$, by an angle, $\theta$, is defined as:

$$ R(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta & 0 \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} $$

docs.title: Rotational Transformation:¶
docs.text: Position Example Transformation Transformation Matrix $R(\frac{2\pi}{2}) = C_2$ Rotation by $\frac{2\pi}{2} = \pi$ rotation counterclockwise about the $C_2$ axis $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $-$ $R(\frac{2\pi}{3}) = C_3$ Rotation by $\frac{2\pi}{3}$ rotation counterclockwise about the $C_3$ axis $$\begin{bmatrix} -1/2 & -\sqrt{3}/2 & 0 \\ \sqrt{3}/2 & -1/2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $-$ $R(\frac{2\pi}{4}) = C_4$ Rotation by $\frac{2\pi}{4} = \frac{\pi}{2}$ rotation counterclockwise about the $C_4$ axis $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $-$ $R(\frac{2\pi}{6}) = C_6$ Rotation by $\frac{2\pi}{6} = \frac{\pi}{3}$ rotation counterclockwise about the $C_6$ axis $$\begin{bmatrix} -1/2 & -\sqrt{3}/2 & 0 \\ \sqrt{3}/2 & -1/2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $-$ on Axis $C_n$ $C_n:(0,0,z) \rightarrow (0,0,z')$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = 1$$

docs.title: Powers of Rotations¶
docs.text:
The powers of a rotation are defined as follows:

$$R^n(\theta) = \underbrace{R(\theta)R(\theta)R(\theta)...R(\theta)}_{n \text{ times}}$$

For instance, $R^2(\theta) = R(\theta)R(\theta)$.

The powers of a rotation are also rotations. This means that they can be represented by a matrix. For instance, $R^2(\theta)$ is a rotation by $2\theta$ and can be represented by the matrix:

$$R^2(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(2\theta) & -\sin(2\theta) & 0 \\ \sin(2\theta) & \cos(2\theta) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

In general, the powers of a rotation can be represented by the matrix:

$$R^n(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(n\theta) & -\sin(n\theta) & 0 \\ \sin(n\theta) & \cos(n\theta) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

The powers of R other than R itself are reducible and can always be represented by another, simpler matrix. See the table below for examples.

$C_n$ $R^1$ $R^2$ $R^3$ $R^4$ $R^5$ $R^6$ $C_2$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = E$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = C_2^1$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = E$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = C_2^1$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = E$$ $C_6$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & -\sqrt{3}/2 \\ \sqrt{3}/2 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^1$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1/2 & -\sqrt{3}/2 \\ \sqrt{3}/2 & -1/2 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^2 = C_3^1 $$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^3 = C_2^1 $$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1/2 & \sqrt{3}/2 \\ -\sqrt{3}/2 & -1/2 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^4 = C_3^2 $$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & \sqrt{3}/2 \\ -\sqrt{3}/2 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^5 = C6^-1 $$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = C_6^6 = E $$

docs.title: Inversion Transformation:¶
docs.text:
A center of inversion acts to invert all coordinates $(x,y,z)$ to their opposite direction $(-x,-y,-z)$. In quantum field theory this is refered to as a parity transformation and represents one of the fundamental symmetries of the universe (the "P" in CPT symmetry) as currently understood by the standard model.

Position Example Transformation Transformation Matrix General $i$ $i:(x,y,z) \rightarrow (-x,-y,-z)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$ on Origin $i$ $i:(0,0,0) \rightarrow (0,0,0)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} = 0 $$

docs.title: Identity Transformation:¶
docs.text: The identity transformation is the transformation that leaves all points in space unchanged. It is represented by the identity matrix, $\mathbb{I}_3$ or the letter $E$ in Schoenflies notation. Every symmetry group has an identity transformation and every symmetry element has an inverse element such that the product of the two is the identity transformation (just like how the product of a number and its reciprocal is 1).

docs.title: The Identity Element and Inverses:¶
docs.text:
• Every symmetry element has an inverse such that: $$T^{-1}T = TT^{-1} = E$$
  • The inverse of a rotation is the rotation in the opposite direction: $$R^{-1}(\theta) = R(-\theta)$$
  • The inverse of a mirror plane is the same mirror plane: $$\sigma^{-1} = \sigma$$
  • The inverse of the identity transformation is the identity transformation: $$E^{-1} = E$$
  • The inverse of the inversion transformation is the inversion transformation: $$i^{-1} = i$$
  • Rotoreflection inverses are easiest to define by simply equating them to the product of the inverse of the rotation and the mirror plane: $$S_n^{-1} = C_n^{-1}\sigma$$
    • Be careful with odd rotoreflections as the inverse element $S_n^{-1}$ is not the same as $S_n^{n-1} (e.g. S_3^2 \neq S_3^{-1})$.

docs.title: Rotoreflection Transformations (Improper Rotations):¶
docs.text: Rotoreflections are a combination of a rotation and a reflection. They are represented by the matrix product of the rotation and the reflection. For instance, a $S_4$ rotation is a rotation by $\frac{2\pi}{4} = \frac{\pi}{2}$ followed by a reflection in the mirror plane perpendicular to the $C_4$ axis.

docs.title: Matrix Representations of Rotoreflection Transformations:¶
docs.text:
The matrix representation of a rotoreflection is the product of the matrix representations of the rotation and the reflection. For instance, the matrix representation of $S_4$ is:

$$S_4 = R(\frac{\pi}{2})\sigma_{h} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$

We can extend the matrix representation of a rotoreflection to any power of $S_n^x$ by using the matrix representation of the composite transformation and taking the matrix power just as we did for the rotation. For instance, the matrix representation of $S_4^2$ is:

$$S_4^2 = R(\frac{\pi}{2})\sigma_{h}R(\frac{\pi}{2})\sigma_{h} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = C_2$$

docs.title: Table of Rotoreflection Transformations:¶
docs.text: Position Transformation Transformation Matrix General $S_n = R(\frac{2\pi}{n})\sigma$ $$\begin{bmatrix} \cos(\frac{2\pi}{n}) & -\sin(\frac{2\pi}{n}) & 0 \\ \sin(\frac{2\pi}{n}) & \cos(\frac{2\pi}{n}) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$ on Axis $S_n:(0,0,z) \rightarrow (0,0,-z)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} = -1$$ on $\sigma$ $S_n:(x,y,0) \rightarrow (x',y',0)$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} =  \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \mathbb{I}_2$$

docs.title: Week X-Y: Lecture Title¶
docs.text:
Headings will become table of cotents entries in the web page made by mkdocs. The first heading is the title of the page.

Note that HTML tags don't work with pandoc when converting to PDF, but they do work in the notebook and when converting to HTML for the web page. Avoid using them except for the special case of images (see below).

Content within HTML tags are skipped by pandoc when converting to PDF, but properly formatted in web pages created using mkdocs

Objectives

  1. Understand objectives
  2. Learn material

docs.title: 1 Section Headings¶
docs.text: Check out the table of contents on the right of the page. # is the largest heading.

docs.title: 1.1 Subsection Headings¶
docs.text: ## makes a subsection heading.

docs.title: 1.1.1 Subsubsection Headings¶
docs.text: ### makes a subsubsection heading.

docs.title: Subsubsubsection Headings¶
docs.text: At ####, text is now just bolded. It still gets a listing in the table of contents on the right.

docs.title: In line LaTeX¶
docs.text:
• In line LaTeX is surrounded by single dollar signs, e.g. $\frac{1}{2}$ becomes $\frac{1}{2}$.
  • Spaces between the dollar signs and the LaTeX, e.g. $ \frac{1}{2} $ cause errors in some tools (though they appear to be ok in the Jupyter notebook itself and the web page).

docs.title: Block LaTeX¶
docs.text:
• Block LaTeX is surrounded by double dollar signs, e.g. $$\frac{1}{2}$$ becomes $$\frac{1}{2}$$

  • This also works for multi-line LaTeX, e.g.

    $$
| \psi \rangle = \begin{pmatrix}
    a_1 \\
    a_2 \\
    \vdots \\
    a_n
\end{pmatrix}
$$

    becomes

    $$ | \psi \rangle = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ a_2 \\ \vdots \\ a_n \end{pmatrix} $$

docs.title: Images¶
docs.text:
All images must be placed in the docs/images/ directory.

Markdown image formatting works but gives you no control over the size of the image. To control the size, use HTML formatting.

<div align="center">
  <img src="../../images/Capture.PNG" alt="XPS" style="height:10cm;">
</div>

produces

The generate-webpage script will adjust the image path as needed. Due to link handling in mkdocs, the imgage won't be viewable in the notebook in the doct/lessons/ directory, but it will be viewable in the web page.

docs.title: Code Blocks¶
docs.text:
Here's a code block. The web page will show this as code with syntax highlighting (make sure you denote the language in the opening code block tag).

def add(a, b):
    return a + b

docs.title: Using Content from Resources (json files)¶
docs.text: The json files in the docs/resources directory are meant for elements that are likely to be used in multiple notebooks and/or can be used to make standalone web pages.

docs.title: Inserting Equations Into a Notebook¶
docs.text:
When making a lesson in the main lessons directory (i.e., not the docs directory), you can use the function insert_equation() to insert a markdown-formatted equation from the equations.json file. The function takes one required and two optional arguments: the only required argument is the name of the equation; optionally, you can also give the heading level of the equation (the number of #s), and the another path to a json file (it's unlikely you'll need this).

The following cell is a code cell in the original notebook with the following code:

chem224.insert_equation("inner product", heading_level=4)

docs.title: Inner Product¶
docs.text:
$$\langle \phi | \psi \rangle = \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i^* b_i$$

  • $\psi$: a wavefunction describing a quantum state
  • $\phi$: the conjugate of $\psi$ or another wavefunction describing a quantum state

It's akin to the dot product in classical vector spaces but is way more general and powerful. Because it can essentially take the very complicated spaces of wavefunctions and linearize them - making any solution to the Schrödinger equation a vector in the Hilbert space (i.e a linear combination of some orthonormalized basis vectors) (Wikipedia)

docs.title: Making the Equations Webpage¶
docs.text: The generate-equations-webpage script will take the equations.json file and make a webpage with an alphabetical list of all the equations on a dedicated page.

docs.title: Linking to Equations¶
docs.text: Within markdown cells, you can link to an equation on the Equations page using the formatting @EQ: equation name@. For example, @FQ: inner product@ (where FQ should actually be EQ because I have no other way to show the example text in the webpage without converting it) will link to the inner product equation. Markdown formatting doesn't appear to work on the webpage, e.g. @FQ: outer product@ --> outer product, but HTML formatting does, e.g. @FQ: outer product@ --> outer product.

docs.title: Making the Web Page¶
docs.text:
Run the script generate-webpage <notebook name> to convert the notebook in the root lessons/ directory to a mkdocs-compatible notebook in the docs/lessons/ directory, e.g. running from the root directory for this notebook looks like this:

generate-webpage .\lessons\template\template_lecture.ipynb

You can use mkdocs to generate a local build of the website using

mkdocs serve

When you're ready to deploy the website, make sure you've pushed all of the changes to the main branch of the GitHub repository, then run

mkdocs gh-deploy
